User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; ru; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729)
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; ru; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729)

It is impossible to turn off JavaScript support at startup by specifying command line options. For instance: 'firefox.exe -nojavascript'

Calling 
'firefox.exe javascript.enabled false' 
or 
'firefox.exe javascript.enabled "false"' 
also doesn't start firefox with disabled JavaScript support function.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.open command line
2.try to launch firefox with option which turns off JavaScript support
3.
Actual Results:  
firefox starts with enabled JavaScript support 

Expected Results:  
firefox starts without enabled JavaScript support

Command line attributes lists mentioned on the pages:
http://kb.mozillazine.org/Command_line_arguments
and
https://developer.mozilla.org/en/Command_Line_Options
don't contain any relevant command line option description.
comments.creator: mkirill@gmail.com

comments.raw_text: Is this a request to add such a command-line option?  There is no way to start up with "disabled JavaScript support" right now (though you can of course start up with a profile that sets the preference to disable JS).
